comments.commentBody:
Scott Walker, Trump and the Republicans have painted themselves into a corner regarding Obamacare. Every day it becomes increasingly clearer that the immutable laws of economics mean that unless the Republicans want to allow medical underwriting, that is where insurance companies can reject applicants with preexisting conditions, something very close to Obamacare must be retained.

Demand for medical care is inelastic. Controlling prices charged by doctors and hospitals via the use of monopsony like the rest of the developed world does is an anathema to Republicans. Monopsony, meaning "single buyer" is the flip side of monopoly. A monopsonist sets prices below free market equilibrium. It does not matter if there is an actual single payer or many buyers (or payers) whose prices are set by the government or by insurance companies in collusion with each other. see: Obamacare And Beyond: The Outlook For The Healthcare Sector. http://seekingalpha.com/article/1647632

As it is dawning on the Republicans, any system that does not explicitly control prices must have mandates and subsidies similar to those in Obamacare. Otherwise, most individual insurance policies would be far beyond the reach of middle class Americans since, without medical underwriting insurance companies would have to price their policies based on the assumption that the applicant has a costly preexisting condition..."
http://seekingalpha.com/article/4042715

There is clearly a much deeper story here. If during the campaign Trump "associates" had multiple and extensive unlawful contact with agents of the Russian government for the purpose of affecting the outcome of the election, those personal contacts did not instantly cease after Election Day; rather, they likely evolved into relationships that further strengthen Russia's influence on the Trump administration. Furthermore, given the action taken by FBI Director Comey late in the campaign that undermined Clinton, combined with his refusal to share with Congress intelligence about the current investigation, we certainly ought to be questioning the motives and methods of that agency.
Not unless you are going to get the panhandler education or a job instead.

As an Afro-American I say that Jeff Sessions must be fired immediately.

I can state that neither Martin Luther King nor Malcom X had any relations with Russian diplomats in promoting their missions of peace and tolerance.

Yet both were assassinated.

For this reason Sessions should be quickly put on trial for treason, yet also a capital offense.

Despite the Trump hate machine, government officials must learn never to talk to foreign ambassadors. These are there for their foreign countrymen.

To resist the Trump hate machine, American politicians must only chat with duly confirmed American ambassadors!

What John Beryle seems to be is missing here in his comments is the unique context in which all these meetings took place i.e.:

An elaborate cyberattack strategy on the US presidential election, and similar attacks on other western allies, aimed at influencing the outcome and undermining western democracies. A campaign encouraged by Trump publicly.

A convention intervention by the Trump campaign to remove the hawkish language on Russia from the party's official platform - the only change it made.

A President with ties to dirty Russian money via extremely large Deutsche Bank loans and extensive Russian investment in his real estate, but who won't release his tax returns

Senior Trump officials lying about contacts with Russian officials, several of whom are members Russian intelligence and/or close to Putin. If there's nothing to see here, why lie?

Trump's public fawning over Putin, itself both suspicious and unprecedented

The ex- MI 5 agent, acknowledged as a credible source and Russian expert, alarmed enough to communicate his report to the FBI. "Unsubstantiated " does not mean "fake news" here - it means still to be confirmed by the way.

And of course Russia is, and will remain, a hostile adversary of the United States. It's not Australia or Sweden we are talking about here.

So these are in no way normal and routine contacts by campaign and administration officials.

His answer was "not responsive" to what Franken asked.He gratuitously gushed that he was a "surrogate" of the campaign and "knew of no such contacts"I imagine he was not denying he had contacts, but rather that he knew of no reason why criminal charges would result from any of the contacts  (including his) which he had personal knowledge of.Insted of answering that he would see to it a full investigation was objectively done upon evidence of criminality if he was confirmed, he gave a "gilding the lily"unresponsive answer that there were no (criminal) contacts.I doubt this is perjury or a violation of the lawyers code of conduct.

Do you honestly believe that America could or would stop meddling in the affairs of other countries? It is in the marrow of our bones. We have been meddling almost as long as we've been a nation. The worse part of our meddling is that we aren't interested in spreading democracy across the planet - we're meddling to make countries better suited for our business interests.
That said, I agree we should stop acting like we're innocents in the world.

Gov. Walker holds the opinion that states should have more power and he laments that "Sadly, the federal government has put up barriers to reform . . ."

Yes, sadly the federal government has stopped states from keeping slavery legal, imposing segregation laws, stripping minorities from the right to vote either through poll taxes, literacy tests, property ownership, and more recently, voter IDs. The federal government refused states to allow factories dumping their waste into rivers (or at least it used to). Maybe states should have their own armies and coin their own money. Or maybe red states should stop taking three times as much money from the federal government as they send to it.

Gov. Walker should have run for president. Oh, wait. He did.
Yes, stand up and walk out of the governor's mansion. For good.

No, Gov. Walker, Republicans in Congress need to heed the protests against repeal of the Affordable Care Act. People are protesting for one of the most basic of human needs (a need which many would argue is a fundamental right) and that is the need for health care and as we all know, access to health care is meaningless if such care is not affordable.

Access to needed health care is not a fringe benefit, it is fundamental to people's well being. People who do not have access to decent, affordable health care cannot function in our society. It is not just a quality of life issue, it is an issue that affects their very ability to hold down a job or to get an education and it doesn't take a Ph.D. in economics to figure out that healthy productive working people contribute to our society.

So, instead of "standing strong" as you put it, Republicans in Congress need to heed their constituents who are protesting. Those elected to Congress, be they Republicans or Democrats or independents have an obligation to listen to their constituents and what their constituents are saying loudly and clearly is that they do not want the ACA repealed or at least repealed without an alternative plan ready and in place.

At the dawn of our nation, a group of men gathered in Philadelphia and drew up the document that became known as The Declaration of Independence and that document begins with the words "We the people," it does not begin with the words we the Republican majority in Congress.

Scotty--Given you concerns about addiction, I'm assuming it's only a matter of time  until you start to address your "Koch" dependency as it's clouding your judgment with increasing grandiosity.  Or did I miss something--you've completed your 12-step recovery program and are now in a position to rehab the rest of Wisconsin?
Please, someone, tell me what a Russian ambassador is doing at the Republican Convention?

With such devastating revelations about Russia playing an active role in tilting the elections in Trump's favour surfacing almost daily, not only the US' national security is compromised badly, but also the Trump presidency stands clearly exposed to the charge of violating the integrity of the US constitutional system, by inviting foreign  intervention in the democratic process of the country.

Either one is against the Constitution Kent-if you didn't know. Fake news are made up stories-this isn't, if you didn't know. Your acceptance of a enemy foreign power interfering in our election speaks volumes about you and rest of  "Trump followers" than it does about him. He has always been transparent to the many that knew him before all of this (presidency): gaudy, a bit of a slime-ball, but most importantly, power seeking. Your excuse and the many sheep that follow-SAD.

No, I think Trump is deeply concerned about a Congressional investigation into his Russian affairs, but the Republicans are willing to tell him they won't investigate right up until he signs all the legislation (and scotus wins) they think they can get away with. Then they better move quickly to take him down or they will appear to have just as much Russian intrigue as he does - which they may.
The only thing our democracy needs saving from is bitter and vengeful resisters with more hatred than substance.

Troubling? I am petrified. There are way too many vacancies in his management team, and the positions that aren't vacant are filled with incompetent campaign workers or people with other Trump connections. We don't have qualified people working in essential positions, and the tweeter-in-chief doesn't seem to care. Petrified describes my state of mind.

its curious how much Bengazi was investigated w/o any results! yet here this could be worse than Irangate...but of course if we just take this administrations word for it...there was no foul play! if there was none lets investigate and set the record straight...we can come to our conclusions with a thorough investigation. what's good for the goose is good for the gander!

Instead of pursuing these disturbing activities as criminal matters involving perjury etc., the most fruitful approach would be to have our non-partisan and very professional intelligence experts investigate them from the standpoint of security issues. Such an approach is much more likely to have bi-partisan support, especially from Republican leaders such as John McCain and Lindsey Graham among others. Examination of Trump's financial affairs and tax forms could be part of such an investigation to establish areas of vulnerability and compromise that the Russian can exploit to their advantage. All the other issues being given so much publicity on the cable news networks are just distractions from the key issue -- what does this all mean with reference to national security?

The richer North (Arab) should be punished for murdering the poorer (Black) South. It' s a class, culture and race war. The war has its roots in Arab slavery and genocide of darker peoples, the native peoples.

Your statement is the classic bigotry. The culprits who committed these medieval acts of barbarism are clearly identified ( The Dinka  soldiers. Their Dinka leadership is at least guilty of commandant responsibility and possibly gave clear instructions to commit these atrocities). Yet you blame the Arabs who live in another country several hundred miles away. By the way, the rich ones are those who plundered the many billions since the country became independent & sent it to other countries ( also the leaders of South Sudan, who incidentally share the same skin color, citizenship & religion as the victims).
The 'North' appears to play little part in what's happening. It's one tribe in the South against another. Sort of Hutus vs. Tutsis replayed?
Um, NATO stepping in is getting involved.

Having worked in Nuba Mountains in 2002 as part of the cease fire agreement between Bashir and SPLA to allow humanitarian aid into the area..then back on a train and advise mission in Juba in 2008-9...then the anticipation of the July 2011 referendum relative to independence from Sudan.

It is so sad, so unfortunate and devastating horrific is South Sudan today. For so many who felt the anticipation of freedom and an improved life..this hope has turned to the most hellish situation since Rwanda.

I know/knew many of the Dinka & Neuer leaders while working (Under US State Dept contract) in Juba..The mission to professionalize the SPLA (Sudan People's Liberation Army) with emphasis on laws of war, humanitarian issues coupled with the vision of an independent state..the newest in Africa.

Reports of gross corruption, genocide of ethnic groups throughout South Sudan and a multitude of crimes against humanity have resulted in the newest African state as a overt failure.

A new government must be former outside the controls/influence of Kiir or Machar.

Let's "hope" the future will be better...

Forming a new government is not a  good idea. It will only turn the country into another libya and Iraq. Reports of genocide and rapes are not real. Only the south Sudanese themselves will solve their if there is no intervention by external actors.

It's hard to imagine - and extremely frightening - that The United States of America has a presidential pretender at the helm who mirrors the "child leader" of North Korea.

WE must get The Con Don and his Top 1% Global Financial Elite Robber Baron/ Radical Religion Good Old Boys' Party/Cabal OUT of our governments at every level. All they know is attack, destroy, kill, rape, pillage, plunder in the name of supposed power and greed and the rest of us pay the price.

Resist. Obstruct. Protest. Ignore their laws that attempt to stifle protests and freedom of speech/movement. WE must not let this stand in America. Not now. Not ever again.

And who is Our Dear Leader loyal to? The American People? or the Russian oligarchs? The only way we're going to find out is through some bipartisan investigations, if that's even possible in the bipolar congress.

The current incarnation of the republicans would be unrecognizable, even to Barry Goldwater. Politics have traditionally stopped at the our nation's shores, but as is glaringly obvious, traditions and norms are being shattered with regularity these days, and mostly by those who claim to favor "traditional values".

Wrong on both counts fact check yourself . Clinton do not give uranium to the Russians. Obama did not give billions of cash to the Iranians. That was their money that was frozen from the sanctions and embargos against them oh by the way that cash was for money that partially was paid for weapons systems purchase from the US approved by Reagan. Of that there wer F14 Tomcats as well as other weapons. If this conspiracys were false why did they no come forward with the fact that they had meetings with the Russians. Why will Trump not release his tax returns. There is obviously something to hide here. Where there is smoke there is fire. Oh by the I have had a Security clearance as part of the experience of doing so you must always report if ever you have had contact with officials or agents of a foreign country it is very specific on that. So again why try to hide it.
